questions.question: Which of the following statements about maxilla-facial trauma is/are false?
options: The major cause of death from facial injuries is asphyxia from upper airway obstruction
The mandible is the most common site of facial fracture
The Le-Fort II fracture includes a horizontal fracture of the maxilla along with nasal bone fracture
Loss of upward gaze may indicate either an orbital floor or orbital roof fracture
questions.explanation: B is false (Nasal bone is most common). D is false in this context because loss of upward gaze is the hallmark of orbital floor (blow-out) fracture/entrapment specifically.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent GIT complication of an extensive burn is:
questions.explanation: Acute gastric dilatation and paralytic ileus are very common early complications of extensive burns due to the stress response. Curling's ulcer is a specific but less frequent complication.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A comatose patient who has sustained multiple closed injures is admitted with severe hypotension. The hypotension is most probably due to:
questions.explanation: In trauma, hypotension is due to hypovolemia (hemorrhage) until proven otherwise. Head injuries do not typically cause hypotension in adults.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard vasovagal attacks all are true except:
options: Usual cause is trauma to trigger area
Psychic trauma is a recognized cause
Atropine is the gold standard treatment of the condition
Usually there is peripheral pooling of blood
questions.explanation: Vasovagal attacks are self-limiting and treated by positioning. Atropine is not the gold standard for routine attacks.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Congenital dermoid cysts are characterized by the following features (except) that they:
options: Occur at lines of embryological fusion
Are often attached to the overlying skin
May cause hollowing of subjacent bone
Are lined by stratified squamous epithelium
questions.explanation: Congenital dermoid cysts are located deep to the skin and are NOT attached to the overlying skin (unlike sebaceous cysts). They are often attached to the underlying periosteum.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most nosocomial infections involve the:
questions.explanation: Urinary tract infections (usually catheter-associated) are the most common type of nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Sebaceous cyst is characterized by the following except that it:
options: Is due to obstruction of a sebaceous gland
Is lined by stratified squamous epithelium
Contains a yellow pultaceous greasy material known as sebum
May occur on the palms and soles
Is always anchored to the overlying skin at the punctum of the obstructed gland
questions.explanation: Sebaceous cysts cannot occur on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet because these areas lack sebaceous glands.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Secondary hemorrhage is usually due to:
questions.explanation: Secondary hemorrhage occurs 7-14 days post-operatively and is almost always caused by infection eroding a vessel wall.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Septic shock responds best to:
questions.explanation: Source control (drainage of septic collections) is the definitive and most important treatment for septic shock. Antibiotics and fluids are supportive but ineffective without drainage.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best guide for the required blood transfusion in haemorrhagic shock is the:
questions.explanation: Central Venous Pressure (CVP) provides a better assessment of intravascular volume status and response to fluid resuscitation than BP or pulse alone in shock.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The earliest sign of hypocalcemia is:
options: Tingling of fingers and circumoral region
questions.explanation: Numbness and tingling (paresthesia) of the fingers and around the mouth (circumoral) are the earliest sensory symptoms of hypocalcemia, preceding motor signs.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following conditions may lead to shock EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Loss of 8% of blood volume (approx. 400ml, similar to a blood donation) is well compensated by the body and does not lead to clinical shock (which usually requires >15-30% loss).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following disease may be transmitted during blood transfusion EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. Hepatitis B and C are blood-borne and can be transmitted via transfusion.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most effective treatment of anaphylactic shock is:
questions.explanation: While Adrenaline is the first-line drug, the provided answer key selects IV corticosteroids, possibly emphasizing their role in preventing late-phase reactions or specific source material.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most serious complication of blood transfusion is:
questions.explanation: ABO incompatibility reactions cause acute intravascular hemolysis, renal failure, and potential death, making them the most immediately life-threatening complication.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most urgent measure in the management of a severely injured patient in the reception room is:
options: Taking blood sample for grouping and cross matching
Securing clear airway and adequate pulmonary ventilation
questions.explanation: According to the ABCDE trauma protocol, Airway (with cervical spine control) is always the first priority before Breathing or Circulation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The untrue statement about desmoid tumors of the abdominal wall is that they:
options: Arise from the rectus muscle or its sheath
Occur most often in multiparous women
Should be treated by wide local excision
questions.explanation: Desmoid tumors are benign but locally aggressive fibromatoses. They invade local tissues but do NOT metastasize.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presented with a painful tender right inguinal hernia and colicky abdominal pain. The abdominal plain X-ray showed multiple fluid levels. The correct management is by:
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation suggests a strangulated hernia causing intestinal obstruction. Urgent surgery (herniotomy) is required to assess bowel viability and release the constriction.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 35-year-old multiparous female presented with a reducible right inguinal swelling which was diagnosed as a hernia. This hernia is most probably:
questions.explanation: Indirect inguinal hernia is the most common hernia type in both males and females. Although femoral hernias are more common in women than men, indirect inguinal is still the most common overall.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 70-year-old man with chronic constipation and abdominal distension has a large left scrotal hernia containing sigmoid colon on barium enema. Operative exploration most likely reveals:
questions.explanation: A sliding hernia occurs when a retroperitoneal organ (like the sigmoid colon on the left or cecum on the right) forms part of the wall of the hernia sac. This is common in large, longstanding hernias.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A patient was operated upon under general anaesthesia at 9 a.m. suddenly at 8 p.m. on the same day, he developed fever of 39Â°C. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Fever within the first 24-48 hours post-operatively is most commonly caused by pulmonary atelectasis (collapse of alveoli).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A young female presented with an extremely tender right inguinal mass which could be an inflamed inguinal lymph node or a strangulated femoral hernia. The best diagnostic measure is by:
questions.explanation: Differentiation between strangulated femoral hernia and adenitis is critical; missing a strangulation is fatal. If the diagnosis is in doubt, operative exploration is the safest course.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Acidosis may be produced by the following except:
questions.explanation: Liver cirrhosis typically causes respiratory alkalosis (hyperventilation) or metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis. Shock, hypoventilation, and DKA cause acidosis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Among the ABO blood groups, agglutinogen A is absent from the cells of:
questions.explanation: Agglutinogen A (Antigen A) is present in Group A and Group AB. It is absent in Group B (which has Antigen B) and Group O.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: As regard TPN:
options: It is the only route of nutrition in short bowel syndrome
May lead to sepsis and pneumothorax
Always indicated in conditions requiring NPO
questions.explanation: Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is used for short bowel syndrome, carries risks of catheter-related sepsis and pneumothorax during insertion, and is indicated when enteral nutrition is impossible.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Ballooning of the thenar eminence with abduction of the thumb and marked oedema of the dorsum of the hand is diagnostic of:
options: Subcutaneous whitlow of the thenar eminence
questions.explanation: Infection of the thenar space causes characteristic ballooning of the thenar eminence and holds the thumb in abduction.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Banked blood is deficient in all of the following except:
questions.explanation: Stored blood accumulates Potassium (hyperkalemia) due to RBC lysis. It is deficient in viable platelets, WBCs, and labile clotting factors (V and VIII).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning direct inguinal hernia, the incorrect statement is that it:
options: Protrudes lateral to the inferior epigastric artery
questions.explanation: Direct inguinal hernias protrude through Hesselbach's triangle, which is MEDIAL to the inferior epigastric artery. Indirect hernias protrude lateral to it.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning post-operative wound infection, which of the following statements is wrong?
options: Is most often due to dead space
Can always be prevented by prophylactic antibiotics
Frequently takes the form of stitch abscess
May end fatally by septic shock
questions.explanation: Prophylactic antibiotics reduce the risk but cannot 'always' prevent infection, especially if surgical technique is poor (e.g., poor hemostasis, tissue necrosis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning potassium depletion, the incorrect statement among the following is:
questions.explanation: Hypokalemia (potassium depletion) is typically associated with alkalosis. Acidosis causes potassium to shift out of cells, leading to hyperkalemia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Hypernatraemia can present by:
questions.explanation: Hypernatremia causes cellular dehydration, particularly in the brain, leading to CNS excitability signs such as irritability, twitching, and convulsions.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In acute respiratory alkalosis bicarbonate level:
questions.explanation: In the acute phase of respiratory alkalosis, renal compensation (excretion of bicarbonate) has not yet occurred, so serum bicarbonate levels remain largely unchanged.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In adult male 70 kg, Intracellular water is about:
questions.explanation: Total body water is roughly 60% of body weight (42L). Intracellular fluid (ICF) comprises 2/3 of total body water, which is approximately 28L (or 28kg).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In adult male 70 kg, Intravascular body water is about:
questions.explanation: Plasma volume (intravascular water) is approximately 5% of body weight. 5% of 70kg is 3.5kg (3.5 Liters).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In adult male 70 kg, Total body water is about:
questions.explanation: Total body water constitutes about 60% of the body weight in an adult male. 0.60 x 70kg = 42kg.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In hemorrhagic shock peripheral vascular resistance:
questions.explanation: In response to hypovolemia, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, causing peripheral vasoconstriction (increased resistance) to maintain blood pressure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In the adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to 'shock lung', the most important therapeutic measure is:
questions.explanation: Mechanical ventilation, specifically with Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP), is critical to keep alveoli open and improve oxygenation in ARDS.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common cause of water toxicity is:
questions.explanation: Water intoxication is most commonly iatrogenic, resulting from excessive hypotonic fluids (e.g., D5W) in patients with increased ADH due to surgical stress.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most hands infections are caused by:
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism for hand infections.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Oligemic shock is characterized by:
questions.explanation: 'Generalized vasoconstriction' describes the fundamental physiological compensatory mechanism characterizing the body's response to oligemia to preserve vital organ perfusion.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The essential pathophysiological disorder in all types of shock is:
questions.explanation: The defining feature of shock is inadequate tissue perfusion and oxygenation, regardless of the cause (volume loss, pump failure, or vasodilation).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following conditions lead to hypokalemia except:
questions.explanation: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia, whereas Thiazides and hyperaldosteronism states (Cushing's, Liver failure) cause hypokalemia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following diseases predispose to surgical wound infection except:
questions.explanation: Hypertension per se does not directly impair wound healing or immunity. Diabetes (DM), Obesity (poor vascularity), and Malignancy (catabolic/immune suppressed) are known risk factors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The hand infection which carries the highest risk of developing osteomyelitis is:
questions.explanation: In a felon (pulp space infection), the pressure rises in the closed compartments of the fingertip, occluding the blood supply to the distal phalanx, leading to bone necrosis (osteomyelitis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The highest concentration of K+ occurs in:
questions.explanation: Succus entericus (small intestinal secretions) has a high concentration of potassium, making fistulas or diarrhea a common cause of hypokalemia.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The hyperdynamic phase of septic shock is characterized by the following signs except:
questions.explanation: The hyperdynamic (early) phase of septic shock presents with warm, flushed skin and bounding pulses ('Warm Shock'). Pale, cold extremities occur in the late (hypodynamic) phase.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The incriminated organism in septic shock may be:
questions.explanation: While Gram-negative bacteria are the classic cause due to endotoxins, Gram-positive bacteria and fungi (Candida) can also induce septic shock.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Among the following statements about branchial fistula, the incorrect one is that it:
options: Commonly results from rupture of a branchial cyst
Usually at the lower third of the anterior border of the sternomastoid muscle
Requires removal of the whole track by the 'stepladder' operation
questions.explanation: Branchial fistulas are typically congenital (persistent 2nd branchial cleft/pouch). A ruptured branchial cyst usually results in a sinus, not a congenital fistula.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning pleomorphic adenoma (mixed salivary tumor), which of following statements is incorrect:
options: Has a very heterogenous histological structure
Presents as a slow-growing firm swelling just below the lobule of the ear
Tends to recur after inadequate excision
questions.explanation: Pleomorphic adenomas are NOT well-encapsulated; they have a pseudocapsule with tumor projections extending through it, which is why enucleation leads to recurrence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Operable carcinoma of parotid is best treated by:
options: Radical parotidectomy with block dissection of LNs
questions.explanation: Malignant parotid tumors generally require radical parotidectomy (potentially sacrificing the facial nerve if involved) and neck dissection for lymph nodes.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Parotid gland is the most common salivary gland affected by following pathologies except:
questions.explanation: Salivary stones (sialolithiasis) are most common in the submandibular gland (80%) due to the antigravity flow and viscous, calcium-rich secretions.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Serous salivary secretion is produced by:
questions.explanation: The parotid gland produces purely serous secretion. The submandibular is mixed, and the sublingual is predominantly mucous.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The false statement about ranula is that it:
options: Is a bluish cyst in the angle between the tongue and the floor of mouth
Usually lies to one side of the middle line
May extend into the submandibular region
Is best treated by complete excision
questions.explanation: Ranulas are best treated by marsupialization. Complete excision is difficult and risks injury to the submandibular duct/lingual nerve.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following salivary gland secretes viscid secretion rich in Ca:
questions.explanation: Among the options, the sublingual gland secretes mucous (viscid) saliva. The submandibular (not listed) is also viscid/Ca-rich.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: True statements about ludwig's angina do not include that it:
options: Is a virulent cellulitis of the floor of the mouth
Usually results from infection with staphylococci
Causes marked swelling in the submandibular region with severe edema of the tongue
questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina is typically caused by Streptococci or mixed anaerobic flora arising from dental infections, not Staphylococcus.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which one among the following statements about cystic hygroma is untrue?
options: Occurs chiefly in the neck, axilla, and groin
Presents as a large soft fluctuating translucent swelling
Is localized to the subcutaneous tissues
May rupture subcutaneously with spontaneous cure
questions.explanation: Cystic hygromas (lymphangiomas) often extend deeply into muscle planes and surrounding structures, making them not merely localized to subcutaneous tissue.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement about salivary calculi is untrue?
options: Are commonest in the parotid gland
May lie in the gland or its duct
Produce recurrent pain and swelling during meals
Contain a high proportion of calcium
May require excision of the affected gland
questions.explanation: Salivary calculi are most common in the submandibular gland (approx. 80%), not the parotid.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the followings are factors affecting wound healing:
options: Type of wound and type of closure
questions.explanation: Wound healing is influenced by both systemic factors (age, nutrition, steroids) and local factors (wound type, blood supply, infection).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Keloids are characterized by the following, EXCEPT:
options: Consist of dense overgrowth of scar tissue
Develop after wounds, burns and vaccination marks
Are particularly common in negroes and pregnant females
Occur most often on the face, neck and front of the chest
questions.explanation: Keloids are benign overgrowths of scar tissue and do not undergo malignant transformation. Malignancy (Marjolin's ulcer) is a risk in chronic unstable scars/ulcers.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is incorrect concerning electrical burns?
options: Usually have a small surface area
Are often associated with massive muscle necrosis
May cause reddish discoloration of the urine
Are best treated by immediate excision and grafting
questions.explanation: Electrical burns often have small entry/exit wounds but cause extensive deep tissue destruction (iceberg effect), so they are rarely just superficial.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In the rule of nines:
questions.explanation: According to the Rule of Nines, each lower limb accounts for 18% of the total body surface area.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most lethal exotoxin of Cl. welchii is:
questions.explanation: Alpha toxin (Lecithinase) is the most potent and lethal toxin produced by Clostridium welchii (perfringens), causing extensive tissue necrosis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most serious post-operative chest complications is:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary embolism is the most potentially lethal post-operative chest complication, often causing sudden death.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The prodromal symptoms of tetanus include the following except:
options: Rigidity or muscular twitching in the region of the wound
Stiffness and twitching of the jaw muscles
questions.explanation: Tetanus does not typically present with high fever in the prodromal stage; fever usually indicates complications or severe autonomic instability later.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The sac of femoral hernia protrudes through the:
questions.explanation: The femoral hernia path involves entering through the femoral ring, descending the femoral canal, and exiting through the saphenous opening.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment of acute tetanus includes the following except:
options: Sedatives, muscle relaxants and mechanical ventilation
questions.explanation: Based on the provided key, wound excision is the exception, likely emphasizing that antitoxin neutralization takes precedence before manipulation. However, standard practice includes debridement.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Trauma induces increased secretion of the following hormones except:
questions.explanation: Trauma triggers a catabolic stress response with elevated cortisol, catecholamines, and ADH. Insulin (anabolic) secretion is suppressed.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: True statements about paraumbilical hernia include the following except that it:
options: Affects females more often than males
Is often associated with divarication of the recti
questions.explanation: Paraumbilical hernias protrude through the linea alba just above or below the umbilicus, NOT through the umbilical scar itself (which defines a true umbilical hernia).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which antibiotics are contraindicated in pregnant females:
questions.explanation: Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy as they chelate calcium, causing teeth discoloration and inhibition of bone growth in the fetus.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is wrong concerning Clostridriurn tetani?
questions.explanation: Clostridium tetani is a Gram-positive bacillus, not Gram-negative.
questions.subject: General Surgery
